none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from H. G. Gathright, October 21, 1885
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from H. G. Gathright, October 21, 1885
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 21 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
Palestine Texas
Oct 21st 1885

Prof L. L Mc Innis
College Station
Texas

Dear Sir.

I suppose when you read this
You will conclude I am a regular beggar.
but I trust that some day I can prove
the contrary - I write to request the loan
of $30 00 - I have been employed for some
time past in the General Offices of the I and
G. N. R R Co. but owing to dull times have
been thrown out. It is impossible to
secure a position of any description in
Palestine. business is stagnant - I wish to
go to North Texas where things are better
and obtain employment - For that reason I
now request this loan hoping that Your
friendship for my father may induce you
to favor me his Son - I make no fine display of

**Transcription Analysis Complete**

Alright, let's get this done. My task is to transform this image of a handwritten letter into a clean, digital transcription, adhering strictly to the provided guidelines and maintaining fidelity to the original text. I've begun by analyzing the image, noting key elements like location, date, recipient, salutation, and the letter's main body. The image clarity is pretty good, and the text is, for the most part, legible. I'll maintain the exact original formatting.

The date and location are in the top right: "Palestine Texas" and "Oct 21<sup>st</sup> 1885". The recipient's details are on the top left: "Prof L. L Mc Innis", "College Station", "Texas". The salutation is "Dear Sir.". The core of the transcription involves meticulous preservation of the writer's words, including all spelling, punctuation (even faint marks), and line breaks.

I'll address formatting, like the superscript "st" in "Oct 21<sup>st</sup>" and the superscript "00" in "$30 <sup>00</sup>". I'll pay attention to characters that might be unclear such as "q" looking like "g" and the spacing and capitalization, specifically with regard to names and places. The name is "Prof L. L Mc Innis". I'll maintain the line breaks from the image for clarity. I'll handle any crossed-out text by either omitting it to transcribe only the final text, or by noting them if needed, adhering to diplomatic guidelines of transcription. The text "I and G. N. R R Co." is not clear. The capitalization is important, and I need to determine the intended spelling of that phrase.

Now, as I'm creating the final transcription, I'm making sure that the line breaks are correct, formatting is good. The text "M<sup>c</sup> Innis" is important, the raised 'c'.

I will provide a plain text transcription with HTML tags for formatting as requested.

The end.

being in desperate circumstances to obtain
Your pity, for such is not the case. I ask you
because it humiliates me less to do so than many
others And if you refuse me I am convinced
that I need expect nothing from others -

Very Sincerely Yours
H. G. Gathright

**Analysis and Transcription of a Handwritten Letter**

Alright, let's break this down. My task is to transcribe this image of a handwritten letter, and I'm treating it like a puzzle. The writing looks like it's from the 19th or early 20th century. First, I need to look closely at each word and make sure the context is right, and there is no mistake about the words.

Okay, line 1 looks like it begins with "being." The 'b' is clear, and the context works: "being in desperate circumstances..." The sentence may be starting in the middle, or on the next page.

Then I get to line 2, which seems to say, "Your pity, for such is not the case. I ask you." So, "pity," then a pause. It is readable, "case." The letters are all distinct and properly formed. "I ask you" â€“ easy.

Line 3, "because it humiliates me less to do so than many," has a bit of loopy handwriting but clear enough: "humiliates," "less," "than many." The letters are distinctive, and it is easy to read.

Line 4, "others And if you refuse me I am convinced," is fairly straightforward too. Here is a capital "And", which is a bit strange, but it has to be noted.

Now, line 5, is where it gets interesting, with "that I need expect nothing from others -" Okay, "that" is easy. But that word between "I" and "expect" - "need". Now, is it "need" - which is a bit archaic here, grammatically, but possible? Or, is it another word? I had to go through a lot to figure this out! It looks like "need," the 'ee's are collapsed into a single 'u' shape due to the cursive. However, this is the correct word as far as the grammar goes. "need" meaning "should" is reasonable in this context.

Then comes the closing, "Very Sincerely Yours." And finally, the signature "H. G. Gathright." I'm pretty sure about the "Gathright," and "H. G." looks right too. So, all done!
